awd_titl_txt: Decision Flow Networks for Effective Classification in Service Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This award advances the security of online communications by improving the process of verifying information posted to social media outlets in near real-time.  Whether through cyber-attacks or inaccuracies, misinformation can have devastating effects on civil society and preventing its spread is considered by Congress to be one of the major security challenges facing the Nation today.  Because today's social media networks are so highly connected, information can spread through social media at great speed.  As information is made public and shared online, the challenge facing online media outlets is to balance the accuracy and speed of news verification in order to avoid epidemics of misinformation.  This project will develop new methods to direct internal (proprietary scoring algorithms) and external (third-party fact-checking) resources in order to detect and disrupt misinformation quickly and accurately.  The research opens new directions in time-sensitive classification problems and has wide application to time sensitive decision-trees involving binary decisions.  This project will provide opportunities for graduate students to learn about cutting-edge security challenges through interactions with online media firms. 
 
Employing a new paradigm that integrates a decision-making framework with queueing-type performance measures, this project studies decision flow networks.  This paradigm extends standard queueing networks by allowing a sequence of decisions to impact knowledge flow and vice versa. Decisions depend heavily on the random processing times and accuracy of agents (e.g., algorithms or fact-checkers) who provide service to the network.  Focusing on decision flow networks with binary decision (e.g., jobs are classified into one of two categories), this award develops novel operations research models that capture the interdependence between the agent's knowledge and the flow of information in the network.  These models integrate decision theory and queueing theory, and the analysis require a mix of robust optimization and stochastic dynamic programming techniques.  This novel approach makes a rich contribution to the existing literature and extends the boundaries of each of these fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In advance to their testimony in Congress in 2017, Facebook, Twitter and Google released disturbing data from the last election campaign cycle. Facebook found that Russian operatives had reached 126 million users (half of Americans eligible to vote), Google discovered 18 YouTube channels tied to Russian trolls, and Twitter disclosed that, between September and mid-November of 2016, Russian-connected bots generated approximately 288 million impressions.  Whether through social media or cyber-attacks, misinformation can have devastating effects on civil society and preventing its spread is considered by Congress to be one of the major security challenges facing the Nation today.

Because today's social media networks are so highly connected, information can spread through social media at great speed.  Social media firms such as Facebook use internal resources (e.g., machine learning algorithms) as well as external resources (third-party fact-checking organizations) to identify false information posted on their networks. This process, however, takes time and the results are not 100 percent accurate. The challenge is to balance the accuracy and speed of news verification in order to avoid epidemics of misinformation. Finding ways to detect false information quickly requires development of new class of mathematical and computer simulation models, which we call Decision-Flow networks.  The goal of this project was to develop new design and control principles for decision-flow networks, focusing on improving speed and accuracy of detecting misinformation in social media.

The outcomes of this project are several folds:

Contribution to Theory: This project developed new and novel methods for modeling and analysis of decision-flow networks.   It extended the new solution method of Robust Queueing Theory (RQT) to the analysis of complex decision-flow networks. These new models can be used to predict how long a post would wait until it is classified as true or false and how accurate those classifications would be.  The proposal also developed easy-to-compute, easy-to-implement and effective policies to manage and control decision-flow networks.  The novelty of these models is that they capture interaction between agents? knowledge and their speed of making decisions and leverage them to design an effective system that can process tasks with high accuracy and high speed.

Contribution to Practice: The outcomes of our theoretical models have established a series of design and control principles that can improve the speed and accuracy of detecting misinformation in social media such as Facebook and Twitter.  The applications of decision-flow networks go beyond social media and include many service operations including those in public sector (e.g., Immigration decision of granting or not granting visa to enter U.S.),  computer and communication systems (e.g., coded distributed storage systems or DDS), and healthcare systems (e.g., managing waiting times in organ transplant systems), among others. Thus, the results also contribute to management practices in these decision-based systems in which agents must process (i.e., make decisions for) tasks that are waiting in queues.  

Contribution to Society: Studies have shown that 62% of Americans get their news on social media. More than 2 billion Facebook users, 330 million Twitter users, 800 million Instagram users are exposed to thousands of items posted on those media every minute. Thus, posting disinformation on social media can have devastating impact on politics, economy, and society. Studies have shown, for example, that online manipulation and disinformation tactics played an important role in elections in at least 18 countries over the past year. Thus, preventing false news from spreading in social media will have a significant and broad impact on societies, nationally and internationally.

Contribution to Education:   Four PhD students working on this project learned how to develop robust optimization models as well as complex queueing and dynamic programming models to improve speed and accuracy of decision-flow networks. This allows them to develop their skills to be used in new emerging social media technology.  Some of the models developed in this project have already been included in undergraduate and graduate courses on service operations management at the department of Industrial Engineering and Management Sciences, Northwestern University.
